content: Bence Bakos is a cognitive psychology graduate student at ELTE. He is also a research assistant at ELTE’s Decision Lab, interested mostly in new methods and best practices in research, as well as philosophy of science.
summary: Bence Bakos is a cognitive psychology graduate student at ELTE. He is also a research assistant at ELTE’s Decision Lab, interested mostly in new methods and best practices in research, as well as philosophy of science.
title: Bence E. Bakos

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50 Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50 Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academia's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview 2

 Create slides using academia’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

content:
Welcome to Slides academia
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")  Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}} Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}} Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}  Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }  Questions? Ask
Documentation

content:
IntroductionIn this post I would like to explore if there is any relationship between the number of COVID-19 deaths in Hungary, and changes in Googles mobility data. One would suspect the there may be a causal relationship between lockdowns and the number of deaths. Do people stay at home more if more people succumb to the disease?
Packageslibrary(tidyverse)library(gtable)library(grid)DataDocumentation for data:
Google Mobility DataOur World in Data COVID-19 datasetImportant to note that the baseline mobility was measured between January 3rd and Feburary 6th of 2020.
# Downloading mobility data from Googledownload.file(url = "https://www.gstatic.com/covid19/mobility/Region_Mobility_Report_CSVs.zip",destfile = "Data/Region_Mobility_Report_CSVs.zip")# Unzipping relevant filesunzip(zipfile = "Data/Region_Mobility_Report_CSVs.zip",files = "2020_HU_Region_Mobility_Report.csv",exdir = "Data")unzip(zipfile = "Data/Region_Mobility_Report_CSVs.zip",files = "2021_HU_Region_Mobility_Report.csv",exdir = "Data")# Importing relevant filesmobility_hu_20 <- read_csv("Data/2020_HU_Region_Mobility_Report.csv")mobility_hu_21 <- read_csv("Data/2021_HU_Region_Mobility_Report.csv")# Downloading and importing COVID-19 data from Our World in Dataowd_covid_HU <-read_csv("https://covid.ourworldindata.org/data/owid-covid-data.csv") %>% filter(iso_code == "HUN")Data WranglingGoogles mobility data is divided into separate files by year. Below I join the dataframes and create a separate DF for Hungary overall, and a DF with all subregions. Mobility data and COVID-19 data also need to be joined.
# Joining dataframesmobility_hu <- bind_rows(mobility_hu_20, mobility_hu_21)# New dataframe for Hungary overallmobility_hu_OVR <-mobility_hu %>% filter(is.na(sub_region_1) == TRUE) %>% select(date:last_col())# New dataframe for subregions of Hungarymobility_hu_sub <-mobility_hu %>% filter(is.na(sub_region_1) == FALSE) %>% select(c(sub_region_1, iso_3166_2_code, date:last_col()))# Selecting relevant variablesowd_covid_HU <-owd_covid_HU %>% select(c(date, new_cases:new_deaths_smoothed_per_million,people_vaccinated:new_vaccinations_smoothed,people_fully_vaccinated_per_hundred:new_vaccinations_smoothed_per_million))# Joining mobility and COVID-19 datamobility_covid <- mobility_hu_OVR %>% left_join(owd_covid_HU, by = "date")# Joining mobility and COVID-19 data for subregionsmobility_covid_subregions <-mobility_hu_sub %>% left_join(owd_covid_HU, by = "date")Now we have some beautiful dataframes:1
glimpse(mobility_covid)## Rows: 469## Columns: 24## $ date <date> 2020-02-15, 2020-0~## $ retail_and_recreation_percent_change_from_baseline <dbl> 14, 20, 6, 5, 3, 4,~## $ grocery_and_pharmacy_percent_change_from_baseline <dbl> 6, 10, 4, 4, 2, 2, ~## $ parks_percent_change_from_baseline <dbl> 46, 52, 25, 24, 16,~## $ transit_stations_percent_change_from_baseline <dbl> 16, 18, 6, 5, 2, 4,~## $ workplaces_percent_change_from_baseline <dbl> 4, 3, 3, 2, 2, 2, 1~## $ residential_percent_change_from_baseline <dbl> -2, -2, 0, 0, -1, 0~## $ new_cases <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ new_cases_smoothed <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ total_deaths <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ new_deaths <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ new_deaths_smoothed <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ total_cases_per_million <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ new_cases_per_million <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ new_cases_smoothed_per_million <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ total_deaths_per_million <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ new_deaths_per_million <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ new_deaths_smoothed_per_million <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ people_vaccinated <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ people_fully_vaccinated <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ new_vaccinations <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ new_vaccinations_smoothed <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ people_fully_vaccinated_per_hundred <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~## $ new_vaccinations_smoothed_per_million <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,~Data visualizationRetail and recreationdeath <-ggplot(mobility_covid, aes(date, new_deaths_smoothed))+geom_line(color = "black")+ylab("new COVID deaths (7 day av.)")+theme_minimal()+scale_x_date(date_breaks = "2 month", date_labels = "%b/%g")p1 <-ggplot(mobility_covid, aes(date, retail_and_recreation_percent_change_from_baseline))+geom_line(color = "red", alpha = 0.5)+geom_smooth(se = FALSE, color = "red")+ylab("recreation change (%)")+coord_cartesian(ylim = c(-100,200))+geom_hline(aes(yintercept = 0), alpha = 0.5)+theme_minimal()+scale_x_date(date_breaks = "2 month", date_labels = "%b/%g")+labs(title = "Retail and recreation activity compared to COVID deaths")g1 <- ggplotGrob(p1)g2 <- ggplotGrob(death)g <- rbind(g1, g2) # stack the two plotsg$widths <- unit.pmax(g1$widths, g2$widths) # use the largest widthsgrid.newpage()grid.draw(g)As we can see, peoples recreational and retail movements have significantly dipped during the winter and early spring months.
ParksHungarians enjoyed an almost insanely free summer and it is backed up by the data. People spent more time in parks throughout the whole year, except in the winter.
Transit stationsAs expected, public transportation companies took a big hit. We are getting closer to the baseline level, but people travelled much less during the entire period of COVID.
WorkplacesWorkplace data seems similar to the transportation data. It seems that those who could work in home office are still working from home.
Residental areasSurprisingly there were no big changes in the residential area mobility data. There can be a lot of explanations for this, e.g.
people did not take the quarantine seriously,measurements are not accurate enough,the quarantine measures were not strict enough, etc.ConclusionsThere doesnt seem to be a huge relationship between mobility data and COVID deaths, but this short data visualization practice is not enough to confirm this just yet. Stay tuned for a newer version of this post and even more posts!
We have a few days of NAs in the COVID data, as it did not appear until the 3rd of March 2020.
summary: Is there a connection between Google's mobility data and COVID-19 deaths in Hungary?
title: Hungarian COVID-19 deaths vs. Google's mobility data
